# TMF Self-Assessment Guide for Small Water Systems

## What is TMF Capacity?

TMF stands for Technical, Managerial, and Financial capacity - the three pillars of sustainable water system operation. California requires TMF assessments for new systems, ownership changes, and funding applications. The [Division of Drinking Water](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) administers these requirements.

**Why It Matters:**
- Required by state and federal law (SDWA 1996)
- Demonstrates long-term viability
- Identifies gaps before they become crises
- Required for most funding programs

## Technical Capacity

Technical capacity means having the physical infrastructure and expertise to deliver safe water consistently.

### Key Elements

**Source Capacity**
- Can your sources meet maximum day demand?
- Do you have backup supply options?
- Are sources properly protected from contamination?

**Treatment**
- Is treatment adequate for source water quality?
- Are treatment processes properly operated?
- Is treatment equipment maintained?

**Distribution**
- Is system pressure adequate throughout?
- Are there dead-ends or low-flow areas?
- Are there sufficient isolation valves?

**Certified Operators**
- Do you have the required operator grades?
- Is coverage adequate for system needs?
- Is there backup operator coverage?
- Is continuing education current?

**System Documentation**
- Are as-built drawings current?
- Is operations and maintenance (O&M) plan complete?
- Is monitoring plan established?

### Self-Assessment Questions

1. Can we produce enough water on our peak demand day?
2. Do we have certified operators for our system classification?
3. Do we have an operations plan that operators follow?
4. Are our as-built drawings accurate and accessible?
5. Do we have a monitoring schedule that meets requirements?

## Managerial Capacity

Managerial capacity means having clear ownership, effective governance, and proper planning.

### Key Elements

**Clear Ownership**
- Is ownership legally documented?
- Are water rights established?
- Is service area defined?

**Governance**
- Are roles and responsibilities clear?
- Is there a governing board (if required)?
- Are meetings held regularly?
- Are records maintained?

**Planning**
- Is there a capital improvement plan?
- Is there an emergency response plan?
- Is there a consumer confidence report process?
- Are regulatory contacts current?

### Self-Assessment Questions

1. Is our ownership structure clearly documented?
2. Do we have written policies for operations?
3. Do we have an emergency response plan?
4. Do we know who our regulatory contacts are?
5. Are we meeting all reporting requirements?

## Financial Capacity

Financial capacity means having adequate revenue, sound budgeting, and reserves for the future.

### Key Elements

**Revenue Structure**
- Are rates set to cover all costs?
- When were rates last reviewed?
- Is there a rate-setting process?

**Budgeting**
- Is there an annual budget?
- Are actual expenses tracked against budget?
- Is there budget control (dual signature, oversight)?

**Reserves**
- Operating reserve (3-6 months O&M)
- Emergency reserve
- Capital improvement reserve
- Debt service reserve (if applicable)

**Financial Management**
- Are finances audited annually?
- Is there separation of duties?
- Are records maintained properly?

### Self-Assessment Questions

1. Do our rates cover our full cost of service?
2. Do we have a 5-year budget projection?
3. Do we have reserves for emergencies?
4. Do we have a capital improvement fund?
5. When did we last review our rate structure?

## Where to Get the Forms

### Standard TMF Assessment
- [State Water Board TMF page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html)
- Community systems and nontransient noncommunity systems

### TMF E-Z Form
- For transient noncommunity systems meeting specific criteria
- Simpler documentation requirements
- Same website location

## Getting Help

### Free Technical Assistance

**For Small DACs (Disadvantaged Communities):**
- Office of Sustainable Water Solutions: DFA-TARequest@waterboards.ca.gov
- [Rural Community Assistance Corporation (RCAC)](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/)
- Self-Help Enterprises (San Joaquin Valley)

**For All Small Systems:**
- California Rural Water Association: calruralwater.org
- [EPA TMF Capacity Development program](https://www.epa.gov/dwcapacity)

## Common Gaps and Solutions

| Common Gap | Solution |
|------------|----------|
| No certified operator | Hire operator or contract with neighboring system |
| No emergency plan | Use State Board sample template |
| Rates too low | Conduct rate study, phase in increases |
| No reserves | Start with small percentage of revenue |
| No capital plan | Inventory assets, estimate replacement costs |
| Outdated drawings | Apply for technical assistance grant |

## Take Action

1. **Download the TMF assessment forms** from the [DDW Small Water Systems page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) — use the standard form for community systems or the E-Z form for qualifying transient systems.
2. **Complete all three sections** (Technical, Managerial, Financial) honestly — gaps identified now can be addressed before they become compliance failures.
3. **Request free technical assistance** from [RCAC](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/) or the [EPA Capacity Development program](https://www.epa.gov/dwcapacity) if you need help filling gaps in any TMF area.
4. **Use the assessment to pursue funding** — most state and federal water infrastructure grants require a completed TMF assessment as part of the application.

# Water System Consolidation Pathways in California

## What is Consolidation?

Consolidation is the merging of two or more water systems, either physically (connecting infrastructure) or managerially (sharing management). It's one solution for small systems struggling with compliance, costs, or capacity.

## Why Consider Consolidation?

### Benefits
- Share operational costs
- Access more qualified operators
- Achieve economies of scale
- Meet compliance requirements
- Access better funding options
- Provide more reliable service

### When It Makes Sense
- System within 1 mile of larger system
- Repeated compliance violations
- Cannot afford needed improvements
- Lack technical/managerial capacity
- Operator shortage
- Aging infrastructure beyond repair

## Types of Consolidation

### Physical Consolidation
- Actual connection of water systems
- Subsumed system receives water from receiving system
- Original source may be abandoned or remain backup
- Most common type

### Managerial Consolidation
- Systems remain physically separate
- One system manages both
- Shared operators, administration, billing
- Maintains local ownership/identity

### Extension of Service
- Existing system extends to new area
- Similar to physical consolidation
- Often for unserved areas (domestic wells, state smalls)

## Voluntary vs. Mandatory

### Voluntary Consolidation
- Negotiated between systems
- More flexible terms
- State provides funding assistance
- Faster process typically
- Preferred approach

### Mandatory Consolidation (SB 88)
- [State Water Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) can require
- For systems that "consistently fail"
- 6-month voluntary negotiation period
- Board order if no agreement
- Receiving system compensated

**Consistently Failing Means:**
- Repeated violations of drinking water standards
- Failure to provide safe, reliable water
- Demonstrated inability to achieve compliance

## The Consolidation Process

### Step 1: Feasibility Assessment
- Is consolidation feasible?
- Physical distance between systems
- Capacity of receiving system
- Cost of connection infrastructure
- Regulatory requirements

**Feasibility Factors:**
- Geographical separation
- Topography (can gravity work?)
- Capacity of receiving system
- Water quality compatibility
- Infrastructure condition

### Step 2: Identifying Partners
- Neighboring water systems
- County or city systems
- Special districts
- Investor-owned utilities
- Private companies

### Step 3: Negotiation
- Terms of consolidation
- Rate impacts on both systems
- Infrastructure responsibilities
- Governance changes
- Timeline

### Step 4: Funding
- State funding available (SAFER, DWSRF)
- Grants for disadvantaged communities
- Loans for non-disadvantaged
- Technical assistance for planning

### Step 5: Implementation
- Engineering and design
- Environmental review
- Construction
- System integration
- Customer transition

## Funding for Consolidation

### SAFER Program
- Primary source for DAC consolidations
- Planning grants
- Construction funding
- Technical assistance
- [SAFER program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/)

### Drinking Water SRF
- Low-interest loans
- Principal forgiveness for DACs
- Covers infrastructure costs

### Proposition 1
- Bond funding for water projects
- Consolidation eligible

## Liability Protection

SB 88 provides liability relief for receiving systems:
- Not responsible for prior violations of subsumed system
- Protection for water quality inherited
- Applies to voluntary and mandatory
- Removes a major barrier

## Alternatives to Consolidation

### Regional Partnerships
- Shared services (operations, billing)
- Joint purchasing
- Mutual aid agreements
- Not full consolidation

### Contract Operations
- Hire professional operator
- Maintain ownership
- Access expertise without merger

### Administrator Appointment
- State appoints administrator for failing systems
- Temporary measure
- May lead to consolidation

## Getting Started

### Contact Points
- [Division of Drinking Water](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html) district office
- Office of Sustainable Water Solutions
- [Rural Community Assistance Corporation](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/)
- Potential receiving systems

### Questions to Ask
1. Is there a system within feasible distance?
2. What would connection infrastructure cost?
3. What funding is available?
4. How would rates be affected?
5. What's the timeline?

## Take Action

1. **Assess feasibility** — contact the [DDW Consolidation and Extension of Service program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/waterpartnership.html) to determine if physical or managerial consolidation is viable for your system.
2. **Explore funding** through the [SAFER program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) — grants are available for disadvantaged communities pursuing consolidation, covering planning, design, and construction.
3. **Review the compliance pathway** at the [DDW Compliance and Enforcement page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) to understand mandatory consolidation triggers and voluntary negotiation timelines.
4. **Contact potential partner systems** and request technical assistance from [RCAC](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/) to evaluate connection infrastructure costs and rate impacts.

# Funding Navigator for California Small Water Systems

## Overview of Available Funding

California offers multiple funding programs for small water systems. The best option depends on your system size, community income level, and project type.

## Key Funding Programs

### 1. [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) (Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience)

**Best For:** Small disadvantaged communities, failing systems, consolidations

**Eligibility:**
- Community water systems and state small systems
- Priority for disadvantaged communities (MHI < 80% statewide)
- Systems failing or at risk of failing

**What It Covers:**
- Planning and design
- Construction
- Consolidation projects
- Interim solutions (bottled water, POU treatment)
- Operations and maintenance (limited)
- Administrator costs

**Terms:**
- Grants for DACs and SDACs
- No repayment required for most eligible systems
- Technical assistance included

**How to Apply:**
- Contact Office of Sustainable Water Solutions
- Email: DFA-OSWS@waterboards.ca.gov
- Online through FAAST system

### 2. [Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF)](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/services/funding/)

**Best For:** Infrastructure projects for all public water systems

**Eligibility:**
- Public water systems (community and nonprofit noncommunity)
- Publicly and privately owned systems
- Projects achieving SDWA compliance

**What It Covers:**
- Treatment systems
- Distribution systems
- Storage facilities
- Consolidations/interconnections
- Water meters
- Source development

**Terms:**
- Low-interest loans (half of GO bond rate) — see also [EPA DWSRF overview](https://www.epa.gov/dwsrf)
- Up to 30-year terms
- Principal forgiveness for DACs
- Grants available for DACs/SDACs

**How to Apply:**
- DrinkingWaterSRF@waterboards.ca.gov
- Apply through [FAAST](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/) (Financial Assistance Application Submittal Tool)
- Year-round applications

### 3. USDA Rural Development Water & Waste Disposal

**Best For:** Rural communities under 10,000 population

**Eligibility:**
- Rural areas (population < 10,000)
- State/local governments
- Nonprofits
- Tribal entities

**What It Covers:**
- Drinking water systems
- Wastewater systems
- Solid waste
- Stormwater

**Terms:**
- Long-term, low-interest loans
- Grants possible if needed for affordability
- Up to 40-year terms

**How to Apply:**
- [USDA Rural Development California](https://rd.usda.gov/ca)
- Local USDA office
- RD Apply online system

### 4. Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (BIL) Funding

**Special Allocations:**

**Lead Service Line Replacement:**
- $250M to California (FY22)
- Identification and replacement
- 49% must be grants/forgiveness
- No state match required

**Emerging Contaminants:**
- PFAS treatment projects
- Small/disadvantaged community priority
- 100% grant funding available

### 5. Proposition 1 (Water Bond)

**Best For:** Various water projects

**Eligible:**
- Safe drinking water projects
- Disadvantaged community projects
- Administered through various agencies

## Matching Programs to Needs

| Your Situation | Best Program |
|---------------|---------------|
| Small DAC with violations | SAFER (grants) |
| Need consolidation | SAFER + DWSRF |
| Large infrastructure project | DWSRF (loans) |
| Rural area < 10,000 | USDA Rural Development |
| Lead pipe replacement | BIL Lead Line Program |
| PFAS treatment needed | BIL Emerging Contaminants |
| Emergency/interim solution | SAFER |
| Planning/design only | SAFER or DWSRF planning |

## Technical Assistance (Free Help)

### Who Can Help

**Office of Sustainable Water Solutions:**
- Project coordination
- Funding application assistance
- Engineering support
- For small DACs
- DFA-TARequest@waterboards.ca.gov

**Rural Community Assistance Corporation (RCAC):**
- Training and technical assistance
- Funding application help
- rcac.org
- (916) 447-2854

**California Rural Water Association:**
- Operator training
- On-site technical assistance
- calruralwater.org

**Self-Help Enterprises:**
- San Joaquin Valley focus
- Community organizing
- Project development

## The Application Process

### Step 1: Determine Eligibility
- What type of system are you?
- What is your MHI (median household income)?
- What is your project type?

### Step 2: Request Technical Assistance
- Most small DACs should start here
- Help developing project scope
- Help with application

### Step 3: Complete TMF Assessment
- Required for most funding
- Demonstrates system capacity
- Identifies gaps to address

### Step 4: Submit Application
- Through FAAST (Financial Assistance Application Submittal Tool)
- Include required documentation
- Environmental package if applicable

### Step 5: Review and Approval
- Staff review
- May request additional information
- Board approval for larger projects
- Funding agreement

## Tips for Success

### Start Early
- Applications can take 6-12 months
- Start before crisis hits
- Request TA early in process

### Document Everything
- Keep records of problems
- Document community impacts
- Track costs and needs

### Know Your Numbers
- Median household income
- Current rates
- System population
- Violation history

### Leverage Multiple Sources
- Some projects combine funding
- State + federal options
- Grants + loans

## Contact Information

**[State Water Board Division of Financial Assistance](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/):**
- (916) 341-5700

**DWSRF Program:**
- (916) 327-9978
- DrinkingWaterSRF@waterboards.ca.gov

**SAFER/OSWS:**
- DFA-OSWS@waterboards.ca.gov

**USDA California:**
- (530) 792-5800
- rd.usda.gov/ca

## Take Action

1. **Determine your eligibility** using the funding match table above — identify your system size, community income level (MHI), and project type to find the best program.
2. **Start with the [SAFER program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/)** if you're a small disadvantaged community — grants require no repayment and include free technical assistance.
3. **Apply through FAAST** at the [SWRCB Grants and Loans portal](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/) — applications are accepted year-round for most programs.
4. **Request technical assistance early** — contact the Office of Sustainable Water Solutions at DFA-OSWS@waterboards.ca.gov or [RCAC](https://www.rcac.org/events/drinking-water-compliance/) for free help developing project scope and preparing applications.
5. **Explore federal options** through the [EPA DWSRF program](https://www.epa.gov/dwsrf) and [USDA Rural Development](https://rd.usda.gov/ca) for additional or complementary funding.

# Emergency Response for Small Water Systems

## Why Emergency Planning Matters

Small water systems are especially vulnerable to emergencies. With limited staff and resources, a single event can quickly become a crisis. Having a plan before disaster strikes is essential.

## Types of Emergencies

### Natural Disasters
- Earthquakes
- Wildfires
- Floods
- Drought
- Severe storms
- Landslides

### Infrastructure Failures
- Main breaks
- Pump failures
- Power outages
- Treatment equipment failure
- Tank failures
- Source contamination

### Contamination Events
- E. coli or coliform detection
- Chemical spills near source
- Cross-connections
- Backflow events
- Sabotage/vandalism

## Required Emergency Response Plan Elements

### Contact Lists

**Internal Contacts:**
- Operators (primary and backup)
- Manager/administrator
- Board members
- After-hours contacts

**External Contacts:**
- [Division of Drinking Water](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) (district office)
- County environmental health
- Local emergency services
- Mutual aid partners
- Contractors (plumber, electrician, pump service)
- Laboratory
- Equipment suppliers

### Emergency Procedures

**For Loss of Pressure:**
1. Identify cause (break, power, pump)
2. Isolate affected area
3. Notify customers
4. Issue boil water notice if needed
5. Make repairs
6. Flush and sample before restoring
7. Notify regulators

**For Contamination:**
1. Isolate affected source/area
2. Notify Division of Drinking Water immediately
3. Issue public notification
4. Sample to confirm
5. Determine extent and cause
6. Implement corrective actions
7. Clear with regulators before resuming

**For Power Outage:**
1. Assess storage levels
2. Start backup generator (if available)
3. Prioritize essential operations
4. Notify customers of potential issues
5. Arrange fuel for extended outage
6. Monitor continuously

### Alternative Water Supply

**Options:**
- Mutual aid from neighboring system
- Emergency interconnection
- Bottled water distribution
- Water hauling (requires approved tanker)
- Point-of-use filters (for some issues)

**Pre-Position:**
- Know which neighbors can help
- Have interconnection points identified
- Know where to get bottled water
- Maintain tanker contact list

## Public Notification Requirements

### Tier 1 (Immediate - Within 24 Hours)
**Situations:**
- E. coli positive
- Nitrate MCL violation
- Chlorine dioxide MRDL violation
- Any acute health risk

**Methods Required:**
- Media broadcast OR
- Hand delivery OR
- Other approved direct method

### Tier 2 (Within 30 Days)
**Situations:**
- Other MCL violations
- Treatment technique violations
- Monitoring violations (major)

### Tier 3 (Annual)
**Situations:**
- Other monitoring violations
- Special notices

### Boil Water Notices

**When Required:**
- Loss of pressure (below 20 psi)
- E. coli detection
- Inadequate disinfection
- Main break with contamination risk

**What to Include:**
- What happened
- What to do (boil instructions)
- Who is affected
- When you will update
- Who to contact with questions

## Building Resilience

### Backup Power
- Generator for critical equipment
- Automatic transfer switch ideal
- Fuel storage and contracts
- Regular testing (monthly)

### Spare Parts
- Repair clamps and couplings
- Fittings common to your system
- Valve parts
- Chlorinator parts
- Pump seals/impellers

### Mutual Aid Agreements
- Formal agreements with neighboring systems
- Equipment sharing
- Operator backup
- Emergency water supply
- Document expectations

## Post-Emergency Actions

### Before Returning to Normal
1. Confirm problem is resolved
2. Flush system thoroughly
3. Collect bacteriological samples
4. Get negative results
5. Clear with Division of Drinking Water
6. Lift public notification

### After-Action Review
- What happened?
- What worked well?
- What could be improved?
- Update emergency plan
- Replenish supplies used

## Templates and Resources

### State Water Board Templates
- Sample Emergency Response Plan (small systems)
- Public notification templates
- Available at the [DDW Emergency Response and TMF page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/)

### Training
- California Rural Water Association emergency response training
- RCAC workshops
- County OES exercises

## Key Contact Numbers

**Division of Drinking Water Emergency Line:**
- During business hours: Your district office
- After hours: Follow voice prompts

**Spill/Contamination Reporting:**
- OES: (800) 852-7550
- 24-hour availability

**Water System Security:**
- [EPA Water Utility Response](https://www.epa.gov/waterutilityresponse) — emergency planning guides and templates
- [Cal OES](https://www.caloes.ca.gov/) — state emergency management coordination
- EPA Safe Drinking Water Hotline: (800) 426-4791

## Take Action

1. **Download emergency plan templates** from the [DDW Emergency Response page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) — use the state's sample plans as a starting point for your system.
2. **Review EPA guidance** at the [Water Utility Emergency Response page](https://www.epa.gov/waterutilityresponse) for small system-specific planning tools, tabletop exercises, and security assessments.
3. **Establish mutual aid agreements** with neighboring systems — document expectations for equipment sharing, operator backup, and emergency water supply.
4. **Test your plan** — run a tabletop exercise annually and coordinate with [Cal OES](https://www.caloes.ca.gov/) and your county emergency services for larger-scale drills.
5. **Update contact lists quarterly** — verify Division of Drinking Water district office numbers, contractor contacts, and mutual aid partner information.

# Compliance Basics for Small Water System Operators

## Understanding Your Obligations

As a water system operator, you're responsible for providing safe drinking water that meets all state and federal standards. This guide covers the essential compliance requirements for small community water systems.

## Monitoring Requirements

### Bacteriological Monitoring

**What:** Total coliform and E. coli

**Frequency (Community Systems):**
- Population < 1,000: 1 sample/month minimum
- Population 1,001-2,500: 2 samples/month
- Population 2,501-3,300: 3 samples/month

**Sample Locations:**
- Throughout distribution system
- At approved sample taps
- Rotate locations monthly
- Include challenge areas (dead ends, low pressure)

**Response to Positive:**
- Repeat samples within 24 hours
- At original site and upstream/downstream
- E. coli = immediate Tier 1 notification

### Chemical Monitoring

**Inorganic Chemicals (IOCs):**
- Arsenic, nitrate, chromium, etc.
- Typically every 3 years (groundwater)
- Annually for nitrate in vulnerable areas

**Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs):**
- Typically every 3 years
- May require more often if detected

**Synthetic Organic Compounds (SOCs):**
- Every 3 years typically
- Waiver possible in some cases

**Disinfection Byproducts (DBPs):**
- TTHM and HAA5
- Quarterly monitoring typically
- More for larger systems

### Other Required Monitoring

**Lead and Copper:**
- At customer taps (first draw samples)
- Number based on system size
- Triennial or less if action level met

**Radionuclides:**
- Every 3-9 years (groundwater)
- More often for surface water

**Surface Water Treatment:**
- Turbidity (continuous)
- Disinfectant residual (daily)
- Monthly for other parameters

## Reporting Requirements

### Monthly Reports
- Bacteriological sample results
- Chlorine residuals (if chlorinating)
- Treatment data

### Annual Reports
- Annual report to DDW
- Consumer Confidence Report (by July 1)

### Immediate Notification
- E. coli positive
- Nitrate above MCL
- Treatment breakthrough
- Loss of disinfection

## Consumer Confidence Report (CCR)

**What:** Annual water quality report to customers

**When:** Delivered by July 1 each year (for prior calendar year)

**Who:** All community water systems

**Contents:**
- Source of water
- Detected contaminants
- Comparison to standards
- Health effects language (required text)
- Contact information
- Encouragement to participate

**Delivery:**
- Mail, email, or web posting (with notification)
- Keep copies for 5 years

## Maximum Contaminant Levels (MCLs)

### Primary MCLs (Health-Based)

| Contaminant | MCL | Health Effect |
|-------------|-----|---------------|
| Arsenic | 10 ppb | Cancer |
| Nitrate | 10 ppm | Blue baby syndrome |
| Lead (AL) | 15 ppb | Developmental |
| E. coli | 0 | Acute illness |
| TTHM | 80 ppb | Cancer |
| HAA5 | 60 ppb | Cancer |

### Secondary MCLs (Aesthetic)

| Parameter | SMCL | Issue |
|-----------|------|-------|
| Iron | 0.3 ppm | Staining |
| Manganese | 0.05 ppm | Staining |
| TDS | 500 ppm | Taste |
| Chloride | 250 ppm | Taste |

## Violations and Responses

### MCL Violations
1. Confirm with resampling
2. Notify DDW immediately
3. Issue public notification (Tier depends on contaminant)
4. Develop corrective action plan
5. Implement treatment or other solution
6. Return to compliance

### Monitoring Violations
1. Take required sample ASAP
2. Report to DDW
3. Include in CCR
4. May result in public notification

### Treatment Technique Violations
1. Take corrective action
2. Notify DDW
3. Public notification may be required
4. Document resolution

## Operator Certification

### Required Grades
- Based on system classification
- Treatment and distribution grades may differ
- At least T1/D1 for most small community systems

### Maintaining Certification
- Renewal every 3 years
- Continuing education required
- Pay renewal fees on time

### Shift Coverage
- System must have certified operator available
- Contract operators acceptable
- Document operator hours

## Recordkeeping Requirements

### What to Keep
| Record Type | Retention |
|-------------|----------|
| Bacteriological results | 5 years |
| Chemical results | 10 years |
| Actions taken | 10 years |
| Sanitary surveys | 10 years |
| Public notifications | 3 years |
| CCRs | 5 years |

### Organization Tips
- Keep results organized by parameter
- Maintain log of public notifications
- Document equipment maintenance
- Keep calibration records

## Getting Help

### [Division of Drinking Water](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html)
- Your district engineer
- Compliance assistance available
- Not adversarial - ask before problems grow

### Training Resources
- California Rural Water Association
- AWWA
- [State operator certification courses](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/)
- Online options available

### Technical Assistance
- Request TA for DACs
- RCAC support
- [EPA Small System Compliance Help](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo)

## Take Action

1. **Check your certification status** at the [DDW Compliance and Enforcement page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/compliance/) — ensure all operators are current on certification, continuing education, and renewal fees.
2. **File all required reports on time** — set calendar reminders for monthly bacteriological results, annual CCRs (due July 1), and quarterly DBP monitoring.
3. **Access compliance help** through the [DDW Small Water Systems page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/publicwatersystems.html) — your district engineer can provide assistance before small problems become violations.
4. **Use EPA resources** at the [Small Drinking Water Systems page](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo) for monitoring guides, compliance templates, and training materials.
5. **Keep organized records** — maintain 5-year bacteriological and 10-year chemical result files, and document all public notifications and corrective actions.
